title: Kind-hearted dad pays for stranger's petrol after she was left stranded on the way to work
text:
Amy-Jane White was rushing to get to work at 6.50am this morning - but she panicked when her debit card was declined (Photo: Facebook) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A kind-hearted scaffolder paid for a stranger's petrol after she was left stranded as she travelled to work. 
Amy-Jane White was rushing to get to work at 6.50am this morning - but she panicked when her debit card was declined and she could not afford to pay for her fuel. 
With only ten minutes to get to work on her moped, the 23-year-old began to panic and rang her boyfriend for guidance. 
Both were confused as to why the card had declined and boyfriend Dan, unable to drive, felt helpless as his girlfriend stood stranded at Sainsbury's petrol station at Marsh Mills, in Plymouth. 
But one man, father of four Leon Hewings, said he "felt for her" and put his hand in his pocket to help the young woman out in her moment of need. Leon Hewings, said he "felt for" Amy-Jane White (Photo: Facebook) 
Amy-Jane told the Plymouth Herald : "A guy approached and handed me a card and the money for my petrol. He just said here you go, just pay me back when you can. 
"I did well up a little because you don't really imagine strangers to do something so kind for you." 
The 23-year-old said her moped was her only form of transport and she had no one to come and collect her when she was unable to pay for her fuel. Read More "Help me find the man who ran me over and thank him for SAVING my life", pleads teen 
"It completely made my day, he was definitely my hero. If he hadn't have stepped in I don't know what I would have done. 
"I've only been a carer for four months so it's a new job and I felt the pressure not to be late, with ten minutes to spare I was stressed out." The carer was so chuffed that she had been rescued by Mr Hewings that she posted a status on Facebook to thank him (Photo: Facebook) 
Miss White, who has only owned the bike for four weeks, added: "My boyfriend felt so bad he couldn't help, he was so relieved to hear I'd been helped." 
The carer was so chuffed that she had been rescued by Mr Hewings that she posted a status on Facebook to thank him as she felt he deserved recognition for his good dead. 
Mr Hewings, 40, said that he has sons and daughters of a similar age to Amy-Jane and would hope that others would do the same for his children. 
"Other people just let you get on with it don't they - they stand back and just let you struggle," the family-man said. 
"She was up so early and clearly a grafter but she looked so worried and anxious - I just had to help. 
"I've been there myself, before me and my wife started our scaffolding business we struggled. Leon Hewings said he has been overwhelmed by the response to his kind-hearted gesture (Photo: Facebook) 
"We've scrimped and scraped so I just really felt for her." 
He added: "My two sons were with me at the time and they also offered to pay. 
"Like father like sons," Mr Hewings joked, "they've been brought up properly." 
The father of four, who visits the garage regularly, said he often gives his lose change to those in need. 
"It's just courtesy, I didn't think anything of it until my friend text me and said 'I'm so glad to have you as my friend, buddy'. Read More Man trying to trace 'astonishingly honest' Good Samaritan who handed back Â£50 he left at cashpoint for his mother 
"I asked if she'd been drinking which is when she told me the story had gone viral on Facebook." 
Mr Hewings, who has been self employed for six years, was overwhelmed by the comments of praise and admiration which people had left for him on Miss White's Facebook status. 
He became choked up when telling The Herald that his son's had also commented on the post, saying they were proud of their dad. 
"I'm upset just reading this," he said, "I'm just over-whelmed." Like us on Facebook
